reviews.text: Good architecture. Very beautiful and has a lot of history inside. This is the place where everybody must visit in Spain.
Beautifull Basilica . We took a audio guide which was enough for us, it is detailed tour with interesting facts about building this basilica. Must see when in Barcelona
Did a guided tour. The outside of the church was mind blowing. The inside was nice but real crowded and didn't have as much character as the older cathedrals.

Sagrada Familia is a must! There's something when you step inside that makes you feel the warmth of this place and although the tickets aren't cheap it's definitely worth visiting. We chose the time just before closing when the sun lit the western stained glass windows and it was breathtaking!

Give it 5 minutes.   You’re in Barcelona.  You can’t skip it.   Its really an architectural marvel with a great history and so much a part of Barcelona’s soul.   Don’t be too jaded, lonely planeteers 😑

We were lucky we purchased tickets ahead of time.  Long lines otherwise.  We had an audio tour, which is so important as it explains so much about this unique and beautiful church, so that you understand all the intricate details and the "whys".  I was surprised how much we enjoyed this tour of this church both inside and out.  No other church like it!

Visiting Barcelona for 4 days, it was necessary und indispensable to visit La Basilica de Sagrada Famlila.
Planned by Antoni Gaudi this momumental church just combines so many different types of architectural styles. 
You are able to see it before beeing there. It shows up above most surrounding houses. Just standing in front of it makes you feel so tiny. All around are mass of people, taking pictures and enjoing the view.
If you bought your tickets online before you are able to enter the church in like 4 minutes. To get more information you can borrow a audio guide.
The first steps inside are so stunning. From outside it looks like overloaded but the inside is sober and calm. All people in it are silent and respectful. You can walk through the archways and hear your own steps. Looking up to the windows (mentioned below) introduces a wide spectrum of colours. If the sun is shining through the glasses you are able to see the whole basilica filled with coloured light.
If you have time and booked it before there is the opportunity to take the elevators and run up to some towers. Standing nearly on top of these towers you will get a beautiful sight over Barcelona looking from ocean to Parc Güell.

If you are planning to visit Barcelona, just take time for the Sagrada Familia. Please keep in mind that it will be clever to buy tickets before or you have to visit in not-seasonal months.

I could just suggest everybody to stay a few days in Barcelona. Do not forget to sample some Tapas and good vines.

When we were in Barcelona we went to see Gaudi's amazing Sagrada Familia. this was presented to us as one of the highlights of our trip to Spain and it certainly was and did not disappoint.  Although the outside of this church is spectacular the real beauty lies in the ornate inside with its spectacular cloolours and architecture. Building work has been ongoing for centuries and it is due tio be finally finished in about 5 years time. This is an unforgettabole sight and is an absolute must see experience in Barcelona.
35.00 entry. Spent 2-h there. Most unusual but interesting church. I would not take children under 10-years old

The Sagrada Familia impresses with its size and magnificence. Inside, you get impressed by the colorful mosaics and the high ceilings, each beautiful detail that is very worthwhile, even though I consider the amount charged too high.

I've seen pictures of Sagrada Familia but they don't do it justice.  The walking tour is easy and you learn so much about this amazing building.  As beautiful as it is outside, inside is equally if not more.  We went in the off season and it was still pretty crowded, but it was certainly worth it.
The Sagrada Familia is nothing short of amazing and absolutely the highlight of our Barcelona visit.
No questions, just do it.  Never seen anything like it, and make sure you do the tower (elevator up and stairs down).

I don't know if anyone would consider going to Barcelona and not visiting Sagrada Familia.  If you are, it's a mistake and you should absolutely go.  My husband and I were here in 2010 and did the tower tour, which was worth it.  When we visited in 2020 with our 8 year old son the tower tickets were sold out, so weren't able to go.  We were so happy to find ourselves back in this extraordinary place.  There were definite notable changes between our visits.  Our second visit was a weekday in February and was still absolutely packed.  (This was 3-4 weeks before Spain went on lockdown for Covid19.)

Great inside and out. Very busy place for tourists. Crowded but the experience is worth it. Bring your  nice camera or missed a lot of wonderful scenes. People from all over the world. Will come back.

I had the pleasure to visit Barcelona last year and especially to reach the basilica. I was always impressed by Antoni Gaudi as an architect and I am pleased that I have manèges to see his work. It is incomparable and it is an amazing modern art piece

Amazing place to visit. Interesting story that follows 
construction. Very good spot for taking pictures :)

Very beautiful architecture, inspirational and holy place.    

Stunning church with a great amount of history.  Took an official tour.

We booked in advance, which was great as we were timed for the tour we selected.   Just showed up about 20 minutes in advance to go through security.   

Convenient Metro station right in front of the Basilica and lots of restaurants nearby. 

A very beautiful visit.

This famous Church was designed by Gaudi. It has been under construction for more than 135 years. It is not expected to be completed until 2026.the spires and inside of the Church are spectacular. It is a must see if you go to Barcelona.

What a brilliant piece of architecture....simply awe inspiring and jaw dropping masterpiece. Will definitely revisit once the cathedral is completed. You need an entire day to appreciate the beauty of this structure.

We are not disappointed each time  we visit the Basilica. We saw it first in 1980 . It is much more completed today .  To describe it is to do it a disservice . Come and see it for yourself .The people of Barcelona are friendly and I know you will enjoy your stay.

Truely, one of the best sites in the world to visit.  Try to get a guide and if not able.  Get the head phones.
Love, Love!  I will be back!

I went on a solo trip in September last year, so not the busiest time of the year - shoulder season/months. 

I hadn’t purchased my ticket in advance. This was primarily because I didn’t want to be tied down to a specific date and time, in case I ended up doing something different miles away from there during the booked time! The other reason is that tickets aren’t available if you leave it too late, for example, even a week before you travel or visit Sagrada.

This is why I highly recommend purchasing a ticket in advance. *You will also avoid the long queues.* Luckily it wasn’t too bad - it being in September. I mean I still had to wait for a good 45 minutes if not more. I’ve heard the queues go round on the outside, stretching for God knows how long. Mine was bad enough. 

The other benefit of booking in advance is that you can choose your time. If you’re buying on the spot, and want to get in ASAP, the next entry may be an hour or two away, if not more, as it was in my case. So, as you’ll have gathered by now, loads of time wasted by not buying online advance.

Finally, it’s also cheaper. I could’ve bought the basic ticket (no audio guide) for €17 online, with the added advantage as stated above of instant entry, i.e. no queuing. Instead I had no option but to go for the only available ticket which was with the audio guide for twice the price - €34! All well worth it in the end though.

Hope this helped. Sorry to have kept it too long! :)

When you put the location on your phone and it takes you through some streets, it doesn't look like you're going to arrive in a great place but then this beauty appears straight in your face and what an incredible piece of art and architecture it is. I walked around it at least 3 times and did not want to leave because it just amazed me so much and it was extremely beautiful. All the details, the atmosphere around it, truly amazing!
Wonderful architecture, main must see whilst in Barcelona. Incredible building to take in, both inside and out. Museum worth a walk around too. I precooked our tickets and was glad I did.

La Sagrada Família is one of Gaudí's most famous works in Barcelona. It's a giant Basilica that has been under construction since 1882 (that's not a typing error) and it's not expected to be completed for another few years.  It’s a most see place if you visit the city. You will be blown away by its design and interpretation of how a Cathedral should look.
Beautiful place! Sacred. Must see. Unbelievable architecture! So many elements present. Gaudi, what a genius!

This is THE site to see in Barcelona. This breathtakingly beautiful building is located in the heart of Barcelona and can be seen from various vantage points throughout the city. My wife and I purchased timed tickets well in advance and were able to gain entrance smoothly. Even when the lines appear long, they move fairly quickly for those visitors who have purchased tickets in advance. Tickets are shown, visitors are assigned to a small group with a guide and “whisper radios are provided. A magnificent as the complex appears from the distance, see both the exterior up close with the amazing detail as well as the stunning interior is almost indescribable.

The interior has gorgeous color from the beautiful stained glass windows. The colors were particularly lively on the sunny day that I visited.

During the tour, I learned that Antoni Gaudi, one of Catalonia’s preeminent citizens designed this masterpiece of a building. While the construction started in 1882, construction has continued since; it is anticipated that the construction will be completed in 2026.

One of the best church-monuments I've ever visited!! Outside is not enough!! You have to see the inside as well!! Book your tickets in advance!!! Unique experience and one of its kind monument!!! Just stunning!!!

Unfortunately the building is still under construction but can be explored 75% inside. It’s worth paying the ticket if you’re a fan of building architectural design. Otherwise from my perspective, doesn’t worth the price until is completely done.

There is no question that the Basilica a must see when you visit Barcelona and there are hundreds of amazing corners, views and pieces you have to compliment, no question asked here BUT I did not feel welcome. I know that security is always a priority but every time you asked someone, the answer was very harsh. Overall you had to pay a good amount of money but there was no appreciation. Maybe something to consider.

We booked this 2 weeks in advance on the Sagrada website so we could get one of the limited tickets into the tower (unfortunately we got there and the lift had broke down and we couldn't rebook which was really disappointing).

If you have been to Barcelona then it is impossible to miss the Sagrada Familia, from the outside I can understand people not liking its distinct style (my wife for example wasn't impressed), I personally found it captivating and found somethng to look at from every angle.

When you get inside it's almost a total contrast to the jagged harsh outer facade, inside when the lights hit the stained glass windows you are greeted with some fantastic displays of soft light throughout the building.  

If it is completed in 2026 I will certainly come back and see it in all its glory.  At 33euro per person (including one of the towers, which we got refunded) it certainly isn't cheap and probably only for people who have a real interest in architecture or religion.

A stunning building which to be fully appreciated needs to be seen inside and out and something you shouldn't miss if in Barcelona.
Whilst not an avid visitor of churches this is a must for anyone visiting Barcelona. The story behind the building is amazing but the detail in the architecture is incredible.

Buy your ticket in advance and get the audio guide.  The audio guide adds a tremendous amount of value to what you are seeing.  You will need to look down and look up to see all of there is in this magical Basilica.  I can't wait to return in five years when they think it will be finished.

So we actually Reserved the tower viewing months ahead of time and the day of our visit were told the towers weren't allowing anyone due to maintenance. We were very...make that extremely disappointed because we were told this the day of and we were told we would be getting a credit for the portion of the towers, however we are still waiting on that credit. La Sagrada Familia is a beautiful cathedral and definitely a place not to miss when visiting Barcelona. We cannot wait to come back once the towers are completed by May 2026. But that is a long time away....

We had a stellar cool November day walking around La Sagrada Familia, including strolling nearby neighborhoods, and stopping in for a vegan lunch at La T. For hours we found new and fascinating details in the surreal architecture which is constantly changing during it's 140 year construction.

This was my second visit to the basilica, which is my favourite basilica in the world. It's just so unique and beautiful, multi-faceted and intricate. The inside is the best bit, with light reflecting from the large colourful windows and the high organic ceilings make it very special. I also paid for the highlights tour this time, which was very reasonably priced and gave me some extra insight into the meaning behind the wonderful imagery incorporated in the facades. I 100% recommend.

Dont know what else to say...its unique and so beautiful. A must visit in Barcelona Such an amazing piece of architecture and something to be marvelled at. A nice little park opposite is a good way to soak in the atmosphere
Simply amazing, the masterpiece of Anton Gaudí, Next time we hope to visit inside the Cathedral, Anyway, worths visit and see, if you want to go inside, buy in internet before.
Had a nice visit to the cathedral from a hop on hop off bus and had lunch and took a lovely photo but we couldn't look inside

Gosh, maybe 12 years between visits and seeing documentaries on TV in between, the ground floor is now a special and beautiful place of worship  and not a construction site as it was on my last visit. It is so hard to comprehend the difference. 
As a Kiwi, I feel a special bond with the Basilica, because of all the involvement New Zealand Architect Burry who was instrumental in the design and build.  How proud am I to have a New Zealander so involved in this magnificent building, something I'm sure people from many countries feels.
I did my research and we went in early evening to experience the sun light up the stained glass and we were not disappointed.  The lift to view the nativity facade and the easy 400 spiral steps down.  Last time we climed up and then down - the legs were like jelly at the bottom.
Our visit also timed so that we could gain entry to the crypt which opens for just an hour a day to the public.  You have to leave the Sagrada Familia to enter the crypt, but we arrived in time to simply work in.  What a special place.
My bucket list wish is to see this magnificent place of worship once more time, completed and free of scaffold - I imagine it will be a rare occasion as maintenance will be ongoing.

Absolutely amazing didn’t get tickets in advance as lines not that long in March but would recommend doing so during main tourist season.
The colours and light inside were so beautiful. Construction still ongoing could be completed by 2026/30

Though unfinished, the temple is a Basilica with Art Nouveau architecture & 18 towers.  The Nativity facade depicts birth of Jesus.  Passion facade illustrates suffering, death & resurrection of Jesus.  Interior is 90m long, 60m high.  Decorated ceiling, stained-glass windows, apse with unusual Crucifix rendered as a canopy with lanterns are remarkable.  Open daily, 0900 - 2000 hours.  Metro stop Sagrada Familia, L2 Purple & L5 Blue lines.  The audio guide is useful to understand the symbolism details in each facade and throughout the church.  Book tickets online, in advance, to avoid spending time in queues.  The security check at the entrance is quite thorough.  Best time to go would be around 0930 hours.  Attend mass at 1800 to hear the church organ.  Ticket cost €29 including audio guide.

My teen daughter and I visited in early March.  We did not take a tour but we did attend the International Service on a Sunday morning.  We were in queue by 8:15am and were able to get in.  The church is beautiful inside and out.  Next time I would schedule a tour following the service.  Definitely worth a visit!

Amazing experience visiting Barcelona 
Flywebmakers are team who works hard and also travel around the world 
All advertising what we did in Barcelona was a great impact for local businesses small and big ones 
We see us soon here in sagrada familia
The epic construction should be completed by 2030?  It is 70% completed.  It is so unusual and beautiful.  Gaudi's architecture is so beautiful and he painted with light.

I went to Barcelona for the most part to see Gaudi architecture. I’ve been very curious about his work, but I did not expect to breakdown in tears at the beauty inside the Sagrada Família. It’s like the outside of the cathedral is the religious face we present to the outside world, and the inside is our soul. It’s not a traditional sanctuary and that makes it even more touching for me.

If you had limitless funds and you worked for Disney, this cathedral is what you'd build.  The structure is immense, and bright, and, really, more of a sight (like the Eiffel Tour) than anything "real."

We were amazed by this beautiful building and were totally gobsmacked how wonderful it is. The surrounding area was clean and safe. Unfortunately it was closed due to the lockdown, but will visit again.

The cornerstone of the Basilica of the Sagrada Familia was laid in 1882, but Gaudi took over the design and construction in 1883.  From 1914 until his death in 1926, he devoted all of his time to this project.  Because no government funds have been used, the church continues to be built very slowly—relying on donations.  In 2005 UNESCO declared it a “World Heritage Site,” and in 2010 Pope Benedict XVI consecrated it as a minor basilica. Apparently, Gaudi originally neglected to get a building permit, so now the church has acquired millions of dollars in fines, in addition to the continued building costs.  The entrance fees from 3,000,000 visitors each year + donations keep the project going.  Although the façade did seem like it had developed more since our last visit (over 20 years ago), we agreed that it still looks like a big mess, with cranes sticking out everywhere.  The “glory façade” (front section) does have the colorful mosaic tops and interesting tall spires characteristic of Gaudi, but the back really has no color—all muddy brown—and there are so many things going on that it is hard to focus.  We did not try to visit the inside, since there were still large crowds—even at 7:15 pm.   Despite all the criticism,  it is an awe-inspiring building, the likes of which you will not see anywhere else in the world—so definitely a must-see in Barcelona.

This building is so different and contains so much more than one can see on a single visit. You can't help but be inspired by the scope of it, maybe its not erected to the glory of God but it sure reflects the glory of Gaudi's vision.
This place is completely stunning - it's sheer size, the colour, the sculptures, the atmosphere are all second to none.

I did not go in, but just went on a walking tour on the outside. It's a grand and impressive building. Each tiny detail has a story behind it. I can see why it took so long to built - Gaudi is just too brilliant and architects couldn't catch up! I hope it will be completed within my lifetime as I want to go back to see the full grand masterpiece. Nevertheless, this is still a must-see if you are in Barcelona. It can be very crowded during peak hour, so beware of your belongings while admiring the building.

Go by Metro. Easy to get too. You walk up the steps of the Metro and you walk into the backs of legs at the top of the steps. You think why are you not getting out the way...then you turn around on the flat of the top step which is the the pavement and you look up and simply say Wow...just wow. Honestly it's beautiful. You must go. The prices for going in are set across the city. Best to buy in advance to skip queues. 

The architecture of Barcelona is amazing and the metro is easy to get around. 

There's a lovely park opposite too. 

Lots of nice eateries. Best move away a bit from the site to get the cheapest prices. Closer to the tourist sites...higher the prices.

It's hard to put into words the majestic splendor of Sagrada Familia. On a recent trip to Barcelona, we toured the Basilica and vowed to return when it is "finished" in 2026. The audio tour gave just the right amount of information to help us understand what went on (and what is still going on) to bring Gaudi's vision to life.
Lovely and worth visiting but you won’t need more than an hour to see it all. Security was quick and efficient :)
If you are lucky, you will get in. I strongly recommend that you book a tour, otherwise, you may not be able to find tickets for the day of your visit.
Inside was really mesmerising , though the crowd was crazy, and the queue going inside the cathedral is very long .
Every time I come to Barcelona I must visit this place. I love to sit by the pond and enjoy this masterpiece! Come and check for yourself!
Words can’t accurately describe it. You have to see it with your own eyes! It’s breathtaking and awe-inspiring! Go!

We had been there in 2007 when the inside of it was all under construction with scaffolding everywhere. So to see it completed with the sun streaming through the stained glass shining on the white pillars was amazing! Definitely a place to see as it is the only cathedral being built in modern times and gives you a perspective of how these things could have been built in ancient times without the cranes and modern equipment.

A church that makes you loose your breath. Outside it is huge and really stunning. The first times I saw it I did not know so much. When the story was told it became so much more interesting. Inside Sagrada it feels like a fairytale with all fantastic colours
It’s still under construction, stunningly beautiful!  We didn’t go inside due to too many visitors, the wait was so long..... we just admired from outside, walked around the block.
A must see to truly appreciate the scale and architecture, easy access from the Greenline tour bus route
Last year they were almost finishg the details and the church is worth seeing.. amazing art around the church

I visited Barcelona in March for the third time and this was my second visit to the sagrada Família (the first being in 2008). It is such an amazing place to visit and the number one must see in Barcelona in my opinion. It was extremely windy the day we visited and so for health and safety we were unable to visit the towers which was disappointing however the weather can not be controlled and it just means we will have to visit again! The tickets are easily purchased online outside of the venue full details are listed and I would recommend only purchasing tickets from the official website or at the ticket office as these are the cheapest! Do pay extra for the audio guide it was so worth it and we also purchased the ticket which included access into Gaudi’s house in Parc Güell, that was worth a visit if you are a gaudi fan.

I hadn’t seen any pictures before walking in for the first time and it took me ten minutes to realise that I was just standing in open-mouthed awe at the spectacular interior 
Every tourist site in Barcelona is expensive to visit however the Sagrada is well worth the money. The outside promises much and inside certainly delivers

The Basilica is really overwhelming. To me, the most magnificent part was once you get inside: the way the light comes from the vitraux and plays with the space is unique. You feel so humble, so overwhelmed, even if you are not a catholic, you just want to seat in the praying section and just be. The size of everything is actually fulfiling its purpose: to make you feel small and insignificant in front of God.
Along with this, I must note the strict security check to get in - which is necessary in such places - as well as the priority and assistance for families with strollers.
It is a treat for architecture junkies: you can see so many things combined that it's hard to choose a favourite. My favourite however was the passion facade beeing plain and simple, carved in such a way as to resemble the bones of a skeleton. The Veil of Veronica is so engrossing that conveys the essence of the whole theme.
Don't miss when in Barcelona!!
A must see.  I could spend hours maybe days admiring the beauty of every corner of this composite of masterpieces
Simply an amazing work of architecture by an amazing cultural figure in Barcelona. If you go to Barcelona and do not see Sagrada Familia, you maybe shouldn't bother going to Barcelona.

Must have visited this cathedral 3 times and of those two wines we’ve purchased tickets to go up the passion tower. Both times the towers have been shut, once due to winds and once due to electricity outage. Fair enough I guess but when you keep having to pay to see the cathedral you’ve already seen multiple times it gets a bit frustrating.
The cathedral is simply amazing. I can’t think of a more beautiful cathedral anywhere. You can easily lose a couple of hours here. Try and take it all in. There is so much to see it’s amazing
Beautiful nature, memorable places. We know everything about this country now. Thanks to the tour.multi-faceted, affordable vacation in this city. It was nice to learn about the sights of the area
Couldn’t actually get inside since the meek and mild corona virus had asked for most of Spain to be shutdown. Pity really since the outside was just breathtaking.

In love with this place! The most amazing cathedral ever seen.
I can say it worth every penny to go thete to visit.
... to buy a ticket to see the Basilica inside even plus visting the tower is always worth the money. This Basilica is just AMAZING.
From outside it´s already amazing, but from inside it´s even more inspiring and of course always a MUST to visit it inside AND outside.

What a fantastic beautiful interesting work of art, I was in awe of the many many details, the amazing colours coming through from the stained glass windows just takes your breath away, a must absolutely visit.
Easily accessible via public transportation. Purchase tickets online to avoid waiting in long lines.

Don't miss this Wonder of the World. Its incrediable. Do look online to book in aadvance and investigate the different types of tickets that include tower or other attractions at Guell Park - decide if you want to include as cheaper at this point. We did'nt

This is not to be missed. Its a wonder of the World. Plan your trip and look online and decide what ticket you want. It is cheaper to buy beforehand and then you just queue, or you can go round the otherside of the building and buy on day for a little more. Its not too much but may mean you cannot include the tower if thats what you want. We didnt include as no slots left though inside you can book tower sep but may mean a long wait for available slot. Tickets can include others attractions at Guell Park but we didnt do this so investigate what they are and whether worth it or what you want to do. The Park itself is wonderful for a long stroll around and take a picnic

There are just some things in life that you can't believe your eyes...this was one of them for our group.  When we entered we all just stood there with tears in our eyes...need I say more ;) Enjoy your visit!

I had purchased tickets online to tour the basilica but unfortunately we didn’t get to go inside due to safety concerns with the Coronavirus. We still went to see this fabulous structure. I did some reading online before going so appreciated each facade and tower. So incredibly beautiful.

We loved visiting the Basilica. It was easy to access since we went during low season. We bought our tickets in advance with a set time to enter the basilica. It was worth it. Great experience. There’s great cafes and restaurants to grab a bite. You can literally spent hours in that area.
i recommend to book a guided tour and enjoy your visit. The building inside and outside beautiful. Read about Gaudi and Subirachs. You will love it. Online booking is important.

It was very beautiful and historic
It had great architecture,The entrance to the church was 30 euros and was worth it.

This a wierd yet wonderful building and a little mad to the size and extent. Well worth a visit even if it's only to look round the outside.
Expensive to go in try to book on line on the official website a day or so before the visit for cheaper tickets around 23 euros bit they go very quickly. It gets very busy so keep your belongings safe unfortunately thieves and pick pockets operate all over Barcelona.don't let this put you off just be careful and enjoy

I have never seen anything like this in my life and I doubt I ever will again. However, the entire time I was in there I couldn’t help wondering how many starving, destitute people could be helped with the money being ploughed into this endless building project.
Must see a giant sculpture from Gaudí. At 12:00 noon you listen a monks pray from cassette. Reserve tickets on line.

Such an amazing place - such a shame that we couldn’t go in as it was on corona virus lock down. Outside is remarkable -
Such a beautiful place

This a must, every where you look is spectacular. Interesting & easy to reach. Too windy to go up the towers the day we was there. Book on the day is my tip. This can be done online when you arrive. If not booked on the official site refunds are not given. Don’t use the Booths on las Ramlas they charge more.

This was one place that we both wanted to visited in Barcelona. And we weren’t disappointed. The Basilica was a breath taking sight to behold. And that was just the outside! 

We bought tickets on line and got the audio guide which I recommend is worth getting as it fully explains about the history of the building and the on going construction of the Basilica, though it’s worth getting the tickets before you visit. There is a Metro stop solely for the Basilica. Entry to the sight is through security similar to airport security.

The audio guide builds you up to the inside. And once inside words could not describe the stunning beauty and peaceful tranquility. Colours shone through the windows. Internally was bright and spacious. It was a surprise to find a crypt inside the Basilica. 

The stone carvings were life like and were in different architectural styles.

This is really a do not miss sight. The only thing that surprised us was the towers aren’t as tall as you think.

One word of warning. There are numerous beggars around. The cynical part of me feels they are trying to play on some visitors religious beliefs to donate money.

The basilica is simply breathtaking and awe inspiring in its beauty and spiritual atmosphere. The Nativity facade is so full  symbols of joy and life while the Passion facade drives home the intensity and pain of the crucifixion.  Even with so many people around one can  actually pray and be inspired. The stained glass fills the place with light. The pillars make you feel like walking through a forest . The tower access may be difficult for some who have mobility problems , claustrophobic or have fear of heights. Going up is easy with the elevator but going down is a challenge  with circular stairs that are not always well lighted .

I spent the day here for my birthday and boy will it be one to remember!  I had half an hour to appreciate the beautiful interior before heading up the Nativity tower. As I went up at 9.30 there was no queue. Once out of the lift I took in the beautiful views before making my way down the steps. I did the steps because I thought since I’m here I might as well but in all honesty if I could do it over I wouldn’t. If your claustrophobic and have a bit of vertigo then I definitely don’t recommend it - never the less, it all added to the experience however it was a relief when I finally got to the bottom! Please note that you are asked to put your bag in a locker before going up in the lift so try to have a €1 coin on you for this.  It might also help to remember to take your water out of your bag to bring it up with you / I forgot and really could have done with a couple of sips on the way down.
Make sure that if you have booked a time slot to enter the church in the morning that you stay until afternoon!  My time slot was 9am however I was still there at 12pm and I’m so glad because if I’d of left earlier I would have missed the stunning colours that come through the stained glass windows - it’s magnificent and a must see!  I’m still glad I booked the early slot to avoid the crowds but if you’re short on time and can only do either morning or afternoon then it’s a no brainier, afternoon is a must to see the church lit up in all it’s beauty:-)
As I wanted to explore at my own leisure I chose I was happy to have the audio guide included in my ticket. It was very informative however I found that I was so overwhelmed by the different aspects of the church that I would must what was being said and found myself having to replay a let of the parts twice. If you’re not pushed for time, I would recommend exploring the church twice. First without switching the audio guide on so you can digest everything at your own free will and then second time round with the audio guide playing.  I saw a lot of people holding the guide to their ear to listen so I’m not sure if anyone realises that if you have a pair of headphones or earphones on you that you listen to your phone with you can plug those in, hang the guide around your neck and bobs your uncle your hands free!
I would definitely recommend carrying a lot of snacks from you, maybe even bringing a packed lunch? I was there for many hours and found it came in handy and there are benches along the side of the church where you can sit if you need a break.
At the end of the tour there is a museum which I would say allow yourself about an hour to an hour and a half to explore. Sagrada Familia is the topmost tourist attraction in Barcelona - and there's a reason for that. It is an architectural masterpiece designed by Antoni Gaudi. Efforts are in motion to complete its construction by 2026 - the 100th death anniversary of Gaudi. Overall, it will take close 150 years to build, but it will be worth the wait. The church is open to visitors since 2010. The detail on the interior and exterior is exquisite. Audio-guide is recommended because it will help you appreciate the thought into detailing of each facade of the church. One can spend around 2 hours here.

Book the tickets from official website beforehand to avoid very long queues. There are even some discounts for people below the age of 30 and on specific days for certain hours in evening. My ticket (including audio-guide) cost €12 - would have been about €25 without the discounts. Afternoon or evening is the best time to visit to admire the light through stained glass windows. You can hear the church organ during mass at 18:00.
one of the greatest architectural marvel of all time. Barcelona's jewel of the Iberian Peninsula. It speaks it own language.
This is a can't-miss attraction.  Get a guided tour so you can understand all of the intricacies. The church is set to be finished in 2026 but its already a masterpiece.

The most impressive and beautiful church I have ever been inside or outside. The results of a dedicated life's work by a genius. A must see for anyone's bucket list.

We’d seen plenty of pictures but the real thing is awe inspiring to say the least. When it’s eventually completed it will tower above everything else in the city. The audio tour is worth paying for, simple to use, and available in all languages. Won’t say too much more about the interior/exterior because you have to experience it for yourself, suffice to say the design, workmanship etc is unbelievable. Gaudi was certainly ahead of his time! Paying extra to ‘skip the line’ is also advised, especially during the busier summer months. Definitely a ‘must do’ experience.

Still trying to get my money back!  

This however didn’t diminish the impact of this building which remains under construction and is due to be completed in 2026.  I will
Have to go back.  

The way the natural light inside is used is astounding offering you colours of the rainbow and my photos don’t do it justice.  The unique architecture by Gaudi is glorious and the place feels tactile, warm and welcoming.  It is still a place of worship and is steeped in biblical reference both inside and out and yet it doesn’t come across as being overly reserved.  The sculptures reflect Gaudi and others interpretations of his vision with their own identity enveloped within.  There is so much to take in.  Definitely worth a good couple of hours to embrace Gaudi’s genius and the extensive ambition he had.
